g.text: START
input
downwithracismswitch
Kim Kitsuragi: "And one more thing -- as you've seen, these sorts of attitudes are quite common in Martinaise. So I expect this to happen again. And again..."
You: "It's basic biology."
You: "Relax, I was practising the time-honoured technique known as the 'lie'."
Jump to: [Kim Kitsuragi: ""Let me say just one more thing. As..."]

Kim Kitsuragi: The lieutenant falls silent and looks down at his boots. Whether he thinks you have a point or not, he isn't saying. It's unclear what this means for your relationship. Then he speaks...
Jump to: [Kim Kitsuragi: ""Let me say just one more thing. As..."]
You: "It's not about me. As police officers, we gain nothing by staking out the moral high ground over him."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Our position in Revachol is already precarious: Many people think we're vigilantes as it is. I can't have them thinking we're *racist* vigilantes to boot."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Wonderful." The lieutenant falls silent. His expression is hard to read, but it certainly doesn't look *happy*. Then he speaks...
You: "Wait, am I becoming some sort of Death's Head Racist suddenly?!"
Kim Kitsuragi: "I don't know what you mean by *death's head* but it certainly looks like you're becoming a racist, officer."
You: "I've got nothing against them, but we have a responsibility to future generations."
Kim Kitsuragi: "And what exactly do you think should happen to those with *undesirable* traits?"
You: (Shrug.) "Let Nature sort them out."
Rhetoric: Wait a second. Are you sure you want to go there? Even if you succeed, you're going to fail.
Variable["jam.truckman_rhetoric_blocks_race_justification"]

Kim Kitsuragi: "I've had this conversation enough times in my life. From now on, I'm going to stay out of it. How you choose to respond is your business." He concludes: "Now -- let's get back to the task at hand."
Rhetoric: Hoo boy, we're really doing this.
You: "Well, *actually*..."
You: "Of course. But he's also not entirely responsible for them. I haven't been in this world for long -- already I'm a product of my environment."
Kim Kitsuragi: "I suppose that's a relief. Just be careful how often you avail yourself of this 'technique'. A lie may be useful in the short-term, but they have a way of catching up with you later."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Apology accepted, detective." The lieutenant relaxes. A weight seems to have been lifted from his shoulders.
Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"]
Variable["jam.truckman_rhetoric_blocks_race_justification"]
!(Variable["jam.truckman_rhetoric_blocks_race_justification"])
Kim Kitsuragi: The lieutenant says nothing, waiting for you to continue.
Kim Kitsuragi: "There's a difference between saying something crude -- and an ideological racist."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Stop right there. I know what you're going to say. Don't. Also -- these attitudes are quite common in Martinaise. So I expect this to happen again. And again."

Kim Kitsuragi: "I'm going to *stop* this conversation." He makes a sudden hand gesture. An open palm. "This is Martinaise. People have certain attitudes here. You will find plenty of citizens to agree with you. As for me..."
Jump to: [Kim Kitsuragi: ""I've had this conversation enough..."]
Kim Kitsuragi: "That's good to hear. I don't want there to be any unnecessary friction in our relationship during this *important* case."
You: "That doesn't mean they don't have rights. If they're perpetrators, then we punish, if they're victims, then we help. That's all there is."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Well," he says after taking a moment to collect himself. "You've made your views on the subject quite clear..." Another little pause.
Kim Kitsuragi: "And what point would that be?"
You: "It's only rational for a society to select for the most desirable traits. That's how it works in Nature."
Rhetoric: Okay... feels like this is going to be a *discussion* now.
You: "Maybe he's got a point."
Jump to: [Kim Kitsuragi: ""Let me say just one more thing. As..."]
Rhetoric: Okay. You think there's a way out of this.
You: "I don't really want to talk about it." [Leave.]
Kim Kitsuragi: "There are tens of thousands of people who grew up in Martinaise and somehow managed to avoid becoming racists who yell 'Come here, saffron picker' at passers by."
You: Forget it, this was a dumb idea.
Rhetoric: Are you sure about that?
You: "I was just trying to convey that I understood his grievances and wasn't judging him for having them."
Kim Kitsuragi: The lieutenant looks at you in silence, though you cannot discern if he's judging you or not. "I suppose your reasons are your own."
You: Yes.
You: Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"]
Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"]
!(Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"])
Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"]
You: "You're right. I didn't mean to cause trouble. Sorry about that."
Variable["reputation.kim"] > 3
Jump to: [You: ""You're right. I didn't mean to cau..."]
Rhetoric: Now you're thinking sensibly.
Variable["reputation.kim"] > 3
!(Variable["reputation.kim"] > 3)
You: "Look, what happens when the races get all mixed up?"
Kim Kitsuragi: The lieutenant narrows his gaze. "So you *don't* find his views... say, *unbefitting of a police officer*?"
You: What do you mean? I'm in the right here.
You: "Everyone thinks they're better than other people. Some people are just particularly crude about it."
Kim Kitsuragi: "Let me say just one more thing. As you've seen, these sorts of attitudes are quite common in Martinaise. So I expect this to happen again. And again..."

Kim Kitsuragi: "I've had this conversation enough times in my life. From now on, I'm going to stay out of it. How you choose to respond is your business." He concludes: "But be careful. Now, let's move on."
Rhetoric: Here we go. Zoom in on the mixed races part. It's the best one.
kimihubi
dontberacist
You: On second thought, maybe I don't.
!(Variable["jam.kitsuragi_justifying_racism_to_kim"])
redcheckhubs
Suggestion: Well, now you've done it. Let's see if you can talk your way out of this one.
Drama: We know a *lie*, sire. And it didn't feel like one to us. He chooses to believe though -- for now.
